By a Constitutional Law of 15 March 1990 the term of the Assembly of the S.F.R.Y. was prolonged until 30 December 1990; subsequently, on 15 November 1990, the Federal Council of the S.F.R.Y. decided to extend its term until such time as a new Assembly of the S.F.R.Y. had been formed as a result of pluralist elections.  On 28 December 1990, the Chamber of Republics and Provinces decided to extend until 15 May 1991 the term of office of its delegates representing the assemblies of the Socialist Republics and the Autonomous Socialist Provinces.  On 26 April 1991, the Chamber of Republics and Provinces adopted an amendment to that latter decision prolonging its members' term of office.  On 25 June 1991, the number of delegates in the Federal Assembly of the S.F.R.Y. changed as a result of the secession of the R.S. of Slovenia, Croatia, Macedonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
